text:
Next problem when I'm rewriting my program to be smarter. I have a function:
```function B(h::Array, k::Float64, Bo::Float64)

    B = 2 * k .* h

    B .+= Bo

	return B

end```
and, when I call it:
```function dH(mode, h::Array, q::Array, B::Array, p::Parameterstruct)

    Divider = B(h, p.Parameters["k"], p.Parameters["Bo"]) .* p.Derivativeparameters["dX"]```
the result is:
"ERROR: LoadError: MethodError: objects of type Array{Float64,1} are not callable
Use square brackets [] for indexing an Array.
Stacktrace:
 [1] dH(::String, ::Array{Float64,1}, ::Array{Float64,1}, ::Array{Float64,1}, ::Parameterstruct) at /home/mikko/Desktop/Vesivoima/Ohjelmointi/Julia/Simulaatio_Julia/StVenant_2.jl:27"

What could be the problem now?

elements.text: Next problem when I'm rewriting my program to be smarter. I have a function:

function B(h::Array, k::Float64, Bo::Float64)

    B = 2 * k .* h

    B .+= Bo

	return B

end
and, when I call it:

function dH(mode, h::Array, q::Array, B::Array, p::Parameterstruct)

    Divider = B(h, p.Parameters["k"], p.Parameters["Bo"]) .* p.Derivativeparameters["dX"]

the result is:
"ERROR: LoadError: MethodError: objects of type Array{Float64,1} are not callable
Use square brackets [] for indexing an Array.
Stacktrace:
 [1] dH(::String, ::Array{Float64,1}, ::Array{Float64,1}, ::Array{Float64,1}, ::Parameterstruct) at /home/mikko/Desktop/Vesivoima/Ohjelmointi/Julia/Simulaatio_Julia/StVenant_2.jl:27"

What could be the problem now?

text: The problem is that you have `B` defined both as a function and an `Array`

elements.text: The problem is that you have
B
defined both as a function and an
Array

text: within `dH`, `B` refers to the `Array` passed as the 4th argument. You probably should rename it.

elements.text: within
dH
B
refers to the
Array
passed as the 4th argument. You probably should rename it.

text: Yes, I also just understood. Oh, sorry. :slightly_smiling_face: I'm just changing my way to write this algorithm, so old ways made noise to my brains. :slightly_smiling_face:
